revision.text:
On May 1st, 2010, a ruptured [[ExxonMobil]] pipeline in the state of [[Akwa Ibom]], [[Nigeria]], spilled more than a million gallons into the [[Niger Delta|delta]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Vidal|first=John|title=Nigeria's agony dwarfs the Gulf oil spill. The US and Europe ignore it|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/may/30/oil-spills-nigeria-niger-delta-shell|work=The Guardian|accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref> The spill had occurred at an Exxon platform some 20-25 miles (32-40 km) offshore which feeds the [[Qua Iboe River|Qua Iboe]] oil export terminal.<ref name="reuters">{{cite web|last=Eboh|first=Camillus|title=Nigeria cautions Exxon Mobil on offshore oil spills|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/06/15/nigeria-exxon-idUSLDE65E22C20100615|work=Reuters|accessdate=20 January 2014}}</ref> Exxon Mobil declared [[force majeure]] on Qua Iboe oil shipments due to the pipeline damage.<ref name=reuters /> The leakage in the Qua Iboe oil field discharged about 232 barrels of [[Crude oil|crude]] into the [[Atlantic Ocean]] contaminating the waters and coastal settlements in the predominantly fishing communities along Akwa Ibom and Cross River.<ref name="sahara">{{cite web|title=PHOTONEWS: ExxonMobil Oil Spills In Nigeria's Niger Delta|url=http://saharareporters.com/news-page/photonews-exxonmobil-oil-spills-nigerias-niger-delta|work=Sahara Reporters|accessdate=21 January 2014}}</ref><ref name="newsdesk">{{cite web|last=Clyde|first=Don|title=Niger Delta oil spills dwarf BP, Exxon Valdez catastrophes|url=http://newsdesk.org/2010/06/17/niger-delta-oil-spills-dwarf-bp-exxon-valdez-catastrophes/|work=Newsdesk.org|accessdate=30 November 2014}}</ref>
==Effects== Many locals in the region attest to [[environmental damage]] that allegedly developed as a result of the leak. Past oil spills in the delta's creeks have been left to fester for decades, polluting the air, [[soil pollution|soil]], and [[water pollution|water]] of impoverished communities.<ref name=reuters /> Nigeria sees its future output growth largely in offshore fields and does not want spills there to compound its environmental woes.<ref name=reuters /> Checks by [[Sahara Reporters]] revealed that the fishermen reportedly hauled in fish killed in the ExxonMobil’s oil spill in a location about 20 kilometers from the shoreline and supplied the bad fish to unsuspecting members of the public.<ref name=sahara /> The Nigerian Environmental Rights Action group issued a demand for N51 billion ($100 Million) from ExxonMobil in Nigeria for their failure to compensate fishermen within the coastal areas who suffered devastating losses due to the oil company’s exploration activities and major oil spills.<ref name="justice">{{cite web|last=JINN|title=Exxon Mobil Hit With $100 Million For Akwa Ibom Oil Spill Victims|url=http://justiceinnigerianow.org/niger-delta/exxon-mobil-hit-with-100-million-for-akwa-ibom-oil-spill-victims|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140121060835/http://justiceinnigerianow.org/niger-delta/exxon-mobil-hit-with-100-million-for-akwa-ibom-oil-spill-victims|dead-url=yes|archive-date=21 January 2014|work=Justice in Nigeria Now|accessdate=21 January 2014}}</ref> Thick balls of tar have also been sighted washed upon the shoreline as well as oil slicks.<ref>{{cite web|last=Vidal|first=John|title=Nigeria’s Agony Dwarfs Gulf Oil Spill|url=http://ourworld.unu.edu/en/nigerias-agony-dwarfs-gulf-oil-spill|work=The Guardian|accessdate=21 January 2014}}</ref> The spill has only exacerbated the already growing problem of pollution in the Delta. The Nigerian government estimates there were over 7,000 spills, large and small, between 1970 and 2000, according to the [[BBC]]. That is approximately 300 spills a year, and some spills have been leaking for years.<ref name=newsdesk /> Vast swathes of the Delta have been seen covered with tar and stagnant lakes of crude due to oil spills of the past.<ref name=newsdesk />
==Cleanup effort== ExxonMobil of Nigeria was cited for the reported use of [[dispersants]] near the coast to contain the oil spill.<ref name=justice /> These dispersants were considered a violation of environmental standards in the oil industry.<ref name=justice /> Rev. Samuel Ayadi, Akwa Ibom State Chapter Chairman of Artisan Fishermen Association of Nigeria (ARFAN), said that ExxonMobil was in the habit of using dangerous chemical dispersants which are scientifically proven to be toxic to human and aquatic life to clean up oil spills whenever they occur.<ref name=sahara /> He also noted that dispersants were even more dangerous than crude oil because it breaks down the crude oil and sinks it to the sea bed where it kills fish eggs and fingerlings thereby wiping out generations of fish stock and other sea food and marine creatures that make up the food chain.<ref name=sahara />
==Controversy== Following the May 1 spill, protests by women and youth in the local areas disrupted oil production at Mobil facilities for two days, with reports of soldiers beating protestors, including one woman who suffered a broken leg.<ref name=justice /> Those protests led to a May 20 meeting with stakeholders from the [[Akwa Ibom State Government]], Mobil, and core host communities.<ref name=justice /> Among the topics raised was “the issue of the oil company playing one community against another.”<ref name=justice />
==See also== *[[Environmental issues in the Niger Delta]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== Research for this Wikipedia entry was conducted as a part of a Science of Oil Spills course (EN.530.119.13) offered in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at [[Johns Hopkins University]]. * [http://dropps.utmsi.utexas.edu/ Link to Consortium Website] * [http://gulfresearchinitiative.org/ The Gulf of Mexico Research Initiative]

{{Use Indian English|date=February 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox event | title = July 2012 blackouts | image = | image_name = Indian_states_affected_by_July_2012_power_cuts.svg | image_size = | caption = [[States and union territories of India|Indian states]]{{legend|#991111|Affected 2 days by the [[power outage]]s (on 30 and 31 July)}}{{legend|#bb4444|Affected 1 day by the [[power outage]]s (on 31 July)}} | date = {{start date|2012|07|30|02|48||+05:30|df=y}}-
{{End date|2012|07|31|20|30||+05:30|df=y}} | time = | place = North, East and Northeast India | coordinates = | also known as = | cause = | outcome = | reported injuries = | reported death(s) = | reported missing = | reported property damage = | inquiries = | awards = | url = | website = | notes = }} Two severe [[power blackout]]s affected most of northern and eastern [[India]] on 30 and 31 July 2012. The 30 July 2012 blackout affected over 300 million people and was briefly the largest power outage in history by number of people affected, beating the January 2001 blackout in [[Northern India]] (230 million affected).{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/1096957.stm | work=BBC News | title=Massive power cut hits India | date=2 January 2001 | access-date=18 March 2015}} The blackout on 31 July is the [[List of major power outages|largest power outage in history]]. The outage affected more than 620 million people, about 9% of the [[world population]],{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/31/india-blackout-electricity-power-cuts|title=India blackouts leave 700 million without power|date=31 July 2012|author=Helen Pidd|accessdate=31 July 2012|work=The Guardian}}{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/story/2012-07-31/india-power-outage/56600520/1|author=Hriday Sarma and Ruby Russell|title=620 million without power in India after 3 power grids fail|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=31 July 2012|work=USA Today}}{{cite news|title=India's Mass Power Failure Worst Ever in World History |url=http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=770631 |work=Outlook |agency=Press Trust of India |date=1 August 2012 |accessdate=1 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120801052804/http://news.outlookindia.com/items.aspx?artid=770631 |archivedate=1 August 2012 }} or half of [[Demographics of India|India's population]], spread across 22 states in [[north India|Northern]], [[east India|Eastern]], and [[Northeast India]]. An estimated 32 [[Watt#Gigawatt|gigawatts]] of generating capacity was taken offline. An article in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' stated that of the affected population, 320 million initially had power, while the rest lacked direct access.{{cite web|title=How Many People Actually Lost Power?|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2012/08/01/how-many-people-actually-lost-power-in-india/|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=1 August 2012|author=Tripti Lahiri|accessdate=5 August 2012}} Electric service was restored in the affected locations between 31 July and 1 August 2012.{{cite web|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/news-by-industry/energy/power/power-grids-fail-power-restoration-complete-in-delhi-north-east-50-in-eastern-region/articleshow/15293178.cms|title=Power grids fail: Power restoration complete in Delhi & northeast, 50% in eastern region|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=31 July 2012|work=The Economic Times}}{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/02/world/asia/power-restored-after-india-blackout.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|title=As Power Is Restored in India, the 'Blame Game' Over Blackouts Heats Up|author=Gardiner Harris and Vikas Bajaj|date=1 August 2012|accessdate=2 August 2012|work=The New York Times}} == Background == India is the world's third largest producer and consumer of electricity after the United States and China; however, the electrical infrastructure is generally considered unreliable.{{cite news|agency=Associated Press|url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/smementor/news/indian-markets/how-businesses-pay-for-indias-unreliable-power-system-739304.html|title=How businesses pay for India's unreliable power system|date=2 August 2012|accessdate=3 August 2012|work=SME Mentor}}{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.com/International/wireStory/electricity-grids-fail-half-india-16899933|title=Indian Businesses Weather Blackouts, but at a Cost|date=1 August 2012|accessdate=3 August 2012|publisher=ABC News |agency=Associated Press}} The northern [[electrical grid]] had previously collapsed in 2001. An estimated 27% of energy generated is lost in transmission or stolen,{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-08-01/worst-india-outage-highlights-60-years-of-missed-targets-energy.html |title=Worst India Outage Highlights 60 Years Of Missed Targets |author=Rajesh Kumar Singh and Rakteem Katakey |date=1 August 2012 |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=2 August 2012}} while peak supply falls short of demand by an average of 9%. The nation suffers from frequent power outages that last as long as 10 hours. Further, about 25% of the population, about 300 million people, have no electricity at all. Efforts are underway to reduce transmission and distribution losses and increase production.{{cite web |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/Rs-3600-crore-power-sector-plan-to-cut-Transmission-and-Distribution-loss/2013/07/26/article1702694.ece |title=Address power transmission and distribution losses |author=Express News Service |date=26 July 2013 }} In the summer of 2012, leading up to the failure, extreme heat had caused power use to reach record levels in [[New Delhi]]. Due to the late arrival of [[monsoon]]s, agricultural areas in [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] and [[Haryana]] drew increased power from the grid for running pumps irrigating [[paddy field]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Power-grid-failure-FAQs/Article1-905428.aspx |title=Power grid failure: FAQs |date=31 July 2012 |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=31 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730213932/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Power-grid-failure-FAQs/Article1-905428.aspx |archivedate=30 July 2012 }} The late monsoon also meant that [[hydroelectricity|hydropower plants]] were generating less than their usual production. == Sequence of events == === 30 July === At 02:35 [[Indian Standard Time|IST]] (21:05 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] on 29 July), [[circuit breaker]]s on the 400 kV [[Bina Etawa|Bina]]-[[Gwalior]] line tripped. As this line fed into the [[Agra]]-[[Bareilly]] [[Electric power transmission|transmission section]], breakers at the station also tripped, and power failures cascaded through the grid. All major power stations were shut down in the affected states, causing an estimated shortage of 32 GW. Officials described the failure as "the worst in a decade".{{cite web |url=http://india.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/07/30/power-restored-to-most-of-north-india/ |title=Power Restored to Most of north India |author=Sruthi Gottipatti and Niharika Mandhana |date=30 July 2012 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=30 July 2012}} On the day of the collapse, [[Ministry of Power (India)|Power Minister]] [[Sushilkumar Shinde]] stated that the exact cause of the failure was unknown, but that at the time of the failure, electricity use was "above normal". He speculated that some states had attempted to draw more power than permitted due to the higher consumption. Spokesperson for [[PowerGrid Corporation of India|PowerGrid Corporation of India Limited]] (PGCIL) and the Northern Regional Load Dispatch Centre (NRLDC) stated that [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] and [[Haryana]] were the states responsible for the overdraw. PGCIL's chairman also stated that electrical service was restored "at a record time".{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article3702075.ece?homepage=true |title=Worst outage cripples north India |author=Sujay Mehuddia and Smriti Rak Ramachandaran |date=30 July 2012 |work=[[The Hindu]] |accessdate=30 July 2012}} A senior director for an Indian power company described the outage as "a fairly large breakdown that exposed major technical faults in India's grid system. Something went terribly wrong which caused the backup safety systems to fail." More than 300 million people, about 25% of India's population, were without power. Railways and some airports were shut down until 08:00.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-19043972 |title=Power cut causes major disruption in northern India |date=30 July 2012 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=30 July 2012}} The busiest airport in South Asia, [[Delhi Airport]], continued functioning because it switched to back-up power in 15 seconds. The outage caused "chaos" for Monday morning rush hour, as passenger trains were shut down and traffic signals were non-operational. Trains stalled for three to five hours. Several hospitals reported interruptions in health services, while others relied on back-up generators. Water treatment plants were shut down for several hours, and millions were unable to draw water from wells powered by electric pumps. The Associated Chambers of Commerce and Industry of India ([[ASSOCHAM]]) stated that the blackout had "severely impacted" businesses, leaving many unable to operate.{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Power-failure-in-7-states-no-Metro-Trains-in-Delhi-today/Article1-904035.aspx |title=When the lights went out |date=31 July 2012 |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=31 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120730105408/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Power-failure-in-7-states-no-Metro-Trains-in-Delhi-today/Article1-904035.aspx |archivedate=30 July 2012 }} Oil refineries in [[Panipat]], [[Mathura]] and [[Bathinda]] continued operating because they have their own captive power stations within the refineries and do not depend on the grid. It took 15 hours to restore 80% of service. === 31 July === The system failed again at 13:02 IST (07:32 UTC), due to a [[relay]] problem near the [[Taj Mahal]].{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/01/world/asia/power-outages-hit-600-million-in-india.html?_r=2 |title=Half of India Crippled by Second Day of Power Failures |author=Gardiner Harris and Heather Timmons |date=31 July 2012 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=31 July 2012}} As a result, power stations across the affected parts of India again went offline. [[NTPC Limited|NTPC Ltd.]] stopped 38% of its generation capacity.{{cite web|title=India Blacks Out From New Delhi to Kolkata as Grid Fails Again|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-07-31/india-power-grid-collapses-for-second-time-in-two-days.html|publisher=Bloomberg|author= Kartikay Mehrotra and Rakteem Katakey|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=31 July 2012}} Over 600 million people (nearly half of India's population), in 22 out of 28 states in India, were without power.{{cite web|title=Power crisis now trips 22 states, 600 million people hit|url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/268237/power-crisis-now-trips-22.html|work=Deccan Herald|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=31 July 2012}} More than 300 intercity [[Train#Passenger trains|passenger trains]] and [[Commuter rail|commuter lines]] were shut down as a result of the power outage.{{cite web|title=India's Power Grid Collapses Again|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390444405804577560413178678898|author=Saurabh Chaturvedi and Santanu Choudhury |work=The Wall Street Journal|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=31 July 2012}}{{cite news|title=Multiple grid collapses hit train services again|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/multiple-grid-collapses-hit-train-services-again-398952.html|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=31 July 2012| work=First Post|agency=Press Trust of India}} The worst affected zones in the wake of the power grid's collapse were [[Northern Railway zone|Northern]], [[North Central Railway zone|North Central]], [[East Central Railway zone|East Central]], and [[East Coast Railway zone|East Coast]] railway zones, with parts of [[Eastern Railway zone|Eastern]], [[South Eastern Railway zone|South Eastern]] and [[West Central Railway zone|West Central]] railway zones. The [[Delhi Metro]] suspended service on all six lines, and had to evacuate passengers from trains that stopped mid-journey, helped by the Delhi Disaster Management Authority. About 200 miners were trapped underground in eastern India due to [[Elevator#Mine-shaft elevators|lifts]] failing, but officials later said they had all been rescued.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-19060279 |title=Hundreds of millions without power in India |publisher=BBC News |date=31 July 2012 |accessdate=31 July 2012}} The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA), not normally mandated to investigate blackouts, began to do so because of the threat to basic infrastructure facilities like railways, metro rail system, [[Elevator|lifts]] in multi-storey buildings, and movement of vehicular traffic.{{cite web|title=Blackout expands NDMA's scope|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Blackout-expands-NDMAs-scope/articleshow/15285886.cms|work=The Times of India|author=Vishwa Moham|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=31 July 2012}}{{cite news|title=Power supply partially restored; Modi attacks PM|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/live-power-supply-partially-restored-moily-refuses-to-blame-states-398254.html|accessdate=1 August 2012|newspaper=First Post|date=31 July 2012}} The following states were affected by the grid failure:{{cite web|url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/india-blackout-20-states-60-cr-people-affected/276887-3.html|title=India faces worst blackout as grids collapse hits 20 states, 60 crore people|date=31 July 2012|accessdate=31 July 2012|publisher=IBN}} * states on the northern grid: [[Delhi]], [[Haryana]], [[Himachal Pradesh]], [[Jammu and Kashmir]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], [[Rajasthan]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[Uttarakhand]] * states on the eastern grid: [[Bihar]], [[Jharkhand]], [[Odisha]], [[West Bengal]], [[Sikkim]] * states on the northeast grid: [[Arunachal Pradesh]], [[Assam]], [[Manipur]], [[Meghalaya]], [[Mizoram]], [[Nagaland]], [[Tripura]] The following regions were not directly affected by the power outage:{{cite web |url=http://www.nldc.in/Flasher/Flash%20Report_NLDC_Grid%20Disturbance%20in%20Northern%20Region_31072012.pdf|title=Preliminary report on grid disturbance in NEW grid on 31st July 2012|date=31 July 2012|publisher=National Load Dispatch Centre|accessdate=1 August 2012}} * [[Narora]], [[Renukoot]] and Simbhaoli in Uttar Pradesh * parts of Delhi such as Badarpur * areas served by Sterlite and Ib Thermal Power Station (most of western Odisha) * most of the [[Kolkata]] municipal area (CESC system) As of 2 August, Uttar Pradesh was being supplied about 7 GW power, while the demand was between 9 and 9.7 GW.{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/Lucknow/Northern-power-grid-was-again-on-verge-of-tripping/Article1-908042.aspx|title=Northern power grid was again on verge of tripping|agency=Indo-Asian News Service|date=4 August 2012|work=Hindustan Times|accessdate=5 August 2012}} == Prior disaster-proofing == Before the grid collapse, the private sector spent $29 billion to build their own independent power stations in order to provide reliable power to their factories. The five biggest consumers of electricity in India have private off-grid supplies. Indian companies have 35 GW of private off-grid generation capacity and plan to add another 33 GW to their off-grid capacity.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-08-02/ambani-tata-islands-shrug-off-grid-collapse-corporate-india.html |title=Ambani, Tata 'Islands' Shrug Off Grid Collapse: Corporate India |author=Rajesh Kumar Singh and Rakteem Katakey |date=3 August 2012 |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=6 August 2012}} Some villages that were not connected to the grid were not affected, such as Meerwada, [[Madhya Pradesh]] which had a 14 kW solar power station built by a United States-based firm for $125,000.{{cite news |agency=Reuters |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/as-power-grid-collapse-solar-village-shines/277841-3.html |title=Madhya Pradesh: As power grids collapse, solar village shines |date=3 August 2012 |publisher=IBN |accessdate=6 August 2012}} == Reactions == On the day of the collapse, Power Minister Sushilkumar Shinde ordered a three-member panel to determine the reason for the failure and report on it in fifteen days.{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Greedy-states-send-power-grid-crashing/Article1-905597.aspx |title=Greedy states send power grid crashing |date=30 July 2012 |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=30 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120731035918/http://www.hindustantimes.com/India-news/NewDelhi/Greedy-states-send-power-grid-crashing/Article1-905597.aspx |archivedate=31 July 2012 }} In response to criticism, he observed that India was not alone in suffering major power outages, as blackouts had also occurred [[2011 Southwest blackout|in the United States]] and [[2009 Brazil and Paraguay blackout|Brazil]] within the previous few years.{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/power-grid-failure-makes-370m-swelter-in-dark-as-india-struggles-to-meet-its-vast-energy-needs/2012/07/30/gJQAY4afKX_story.html |title=Power grid failure makes 370M swelter in dark as India struggles to meet its vast energy needs |agency=Associated Press |date=30 July 2012 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=31 July 2012}} ''[[The Washington Post]]'' described the failure as adding urgency to [[Prime Minister of India|Indian Prime Minister]] [[Manmohan Singh|Dr. Manmohan Singh]]'s plan for a US$400 billion overhaul of India's power grid. His plan calls for a further 76 gigawatts of generation by 2017,{{cite web |url=http://washpost.bloomberg.com/Story?docId=1376-M7YDKA0YHQ0X01-79TK1GQCDQF2C5AQ5A383U7GQR |title=Singh's $400 Billion Power Plan Gains Urgency as Grid Collapses |author=Kartikay Mehrotra and Andrew MacAskill |date=31 July 2012 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=31 July 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120805054944/http://washpost.bloomberg.com/Story?docId=1376-M7YDKA0YHQ0X01-79TK1GQCDQF2C5AQ5A383U7GQR |archive-date=5 August 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} produced in part by nuclear power. Rajiv Kumar, secretary general of the [[FICCI|Federation of Indian Chambers of Commerce and Industry]] (FICCI) said, "One of the major reasons for the collapse of the power grid is the major gap between demand and supply. There is an urgent need to reform the power sector and bring about infrastructural improvements to meet the new challenges of the growing economy."{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/india-blackout-on-second-day-leaves-600-million-without-power/2012/07/30/gJQA7j1LMX_story.html?hpid=z1 |title=India blackout, on second day, leaves 600 million without power |date=31 July 2012 |author= Simon Denyer and Rama Lakshmi|work=The Washington Post |accessdate=31 July 2012}} On 1 August 2012, newly appointed Power Minister [[Veerappa Moily]] stated, "First thing is to stabilize the grid and it has to sustain. For that we will work out a proper strategy." He declined to blame specific states, saying, "I don't want to start with the blame game."{{cite web |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/dont-want-to-start-with-blame-game-moily/277050-37-64.html|title=Don't want to start with blame game: Veerappa Moily |date=1 August 2012 |publisher=IBN|accessdate=30 July 2012}} [[India Against Corruption|Team Anna]], the supporters of anti-corruption activist [[Anna Hazare]], charged that this grid failure was a conspiracy to suppress the indefinite fast movement started on 25 July 2012 for the [[Jan Lokpal Bill]] and targeting [[Sharad Pawar]].{{cite web |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/team-anna-calls-grid-failure-a-conspiracy-targets-pawar/276445-37-64.html |title=Team Anna calls grid failure a conspiracy, targets Pawar |date=30 July 2012 |publisher=IBN |accessdate=2 August 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2012-07-30/news/32942082_1_northern-grid-anna-hazare-metro-services |title=Team Anna sees conspiracy in northern power grid collapse |date=30 July 2012 |work=The Economic Times |agency=Press Trust of India |accessdate=2 August 2012}} Some technology sources and [[United States Agency for International Development]] (USAID) proposed that another widespread outage could be prevented by integrated network of [[Distributed generation|microgrids]] and [[distributed generation]] connected seamlessly with the main grid via a superior [[smart grid]] technology, which includes automated [[Power quality#Introduction|fault detection]], [[islanding]] and [[Power quality#Smart grids and power quality|self-healing]] of the network.{{cite web |url=http://www.moneycontrol.com/smementor/mentorade/starting-up/power-crisisgrid-collapse-is-it-time-to-think--739976.html |title=Power crisis and grid collapse: Is it time to think different, small and local? |date=3 August 2012 |work=SME Mentor |accessdate=6 August 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.technologyreview.com/news/428666/how-power-outages-in-india-may-one-day-be-avoided/ |author=Kevin Bullis|title=How Power Outages in India May One Day Be Avoided |date=31 July 2012 |publisher=technologyreview.com |accessdate=9 August 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.sari-energy.org/PageFiles/What_We_Do/activities/smart_grid_vision_for_india_power_sector_june_2010/White_paper-Th_%20Smart_Grid_Vision_for_India/White_Paper_on_the_Smart_Grid_Vision_for_India_-_final.pdf |title=The smart grid vision for India's power sector |date=March 2010 |publisher=USAID India |accessdate=9 August 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1364032111004564-gr1.jpg |title= Enabling integrated network of microgrids and distributed power connected to the grid via Smart Grid technology with [self-healing] |accessdate=9 August 2012}} == Investigation == The three-member investigation committee consisted of S. C. Srivastava, A. Velayutham and A. S. Bakshi, and issued its report on 16 August 2012. It concluded that four factors were responsible for the two days of blackout:{{cite web |url=http://www.powermin.nic.in/pdf/GRID_ENQ_REP_16_8_12.pdf|title=Report of the Enquiry Committee on Grid Disturbance in Northern Region on 30th July 2012 and in Northern, Eastern & North-Eastern Region on 31st July 2012|date=16 August 2012|work=powermin.nic.in|accessdate=28 August 2012}} * Weak inter-regional power transmission corridors due to multiple existing outages (both scheduled and forced); * High loading on 400 kV Bina–Gwalior–Agra link; * Inadequate response by State Load Dispatch Centers (SLDCs) to the instructions of Regional Load Dispatch Centres (RLDCs) to reduce over-drawal by the Northern Region utilities and under-drawal/excess generation by the Western Region utilities; * Loss of 400 kV Bina–Gwalior link due to mis-operation of its protection system. The committee also offered a number of recommendations to prevent further failures, including an audit of the protection systems. == See also == {{Portal|India|Energy|2010s}} * [[Electricity sector in India]] * [[Northeast blackout of 2003]]{{Clear}} == References == {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == * [http://www.powermin.nic.in/pdf/GRID_ENQ_REP_16_8_12.pdf Official report of the enquiry committee] [[Category:2012 disasters in India]] [[Category:2012 industrial disasters]] [[Category:Economic history of India (1991–present)]] [[Category:Electric power blackouts|India]] [[Category:Electric power in India]] [[Category:July 2012 events in Asia]]

{{Infobox galaxy cluster | name = [[Abell catalogue|Abell]] 520 | image = A520-mass+xray+lum-4up-m-1.jpg | caption = Abell 520. Imaged January 2012. | credit = [[NASA]] | epoch = [[Epoch (astronomy)#Julian years and J2000|J2000]] | ra = {{RA|04|54|03.80}}<ref name="NED" /> | dec = {{DEC|+02|53|33.00}}<ref name="NED" /> | constellation = [[Orion (constellation)|Orion]] | member_no = 289+<ref name="Girardi" /> | brightest_member = | richness = 3<ref name="ACO">Table 3, page 24 in {{cite journal | last1 = Abell | first1 = George O. | authorlink1 = George O. Abell | last2 = Corwin | first2 = Harold G., Jr. | last3 = Olowin | first3 = Ronald P. |date=May 1989 | title = A catalog of rich clusters of galaxies | journal = Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series | volume = 70 | issue = May 1989 | pages = 1–138 | format = PDF | bibcode = 1989ApJS...70....1A | doi = 10.1086/191333 | url = http://articles.adsabs.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/nph-iarticle_query?bibcode=1989ApJS...70....1A&page_ind=0&epage_ind=137&type=PRINTER&data_type=PDF_HIGH&email=&emailsize=500&emailsplit=YES&send=GET&verified=YES }}</ref> | bmtype = III<ref name="ACO" /> | velocity_dispersion = 1,066 km/s<ref name="Girardi" /> | redshift = 0.2<ref name="Struble">{{cite journal | last1 = Struble | first1 = Mitchell F. | last2 = Rood | first2 = Herbert J. |date=November 1999 | title = A Compilation of Redshifts and Velocity Dispersions for ACO Clusters | journal = The Astrophysical Journal Supplement Series | volume = 125 | issue = 1 | pages = 35–71 | bibcode = 1999ApJS..125...35S | doi = 10.1086/313274 }}</ref><ref name="Ebeling">{{cite journal | last1 = Ebeling | first1 = H. | last2 = Edge | first2 = A. C. | display-authors = etal |date=December 1998 | title = The ROSAT Brightest Cluster Sample - I. The compilation of the sample and the cluster log N-log S distribution | journal = [[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]] | volume = 301 | issue = 4 | pages = 881–914 | bibcode = 1998MNRAS.301..881E | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-8711.1998.01949.x |arxiv = astro-ph/9812394 }}</ref> | distance = {{convert|811|Mpc|Mly|0|abbr=on|lk=on}} {{hub|0.705}} <ref name="NED">{{cite web | url = http://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/nph-objsearch?objname=Abell+520&extend=no | title = NED results for object ABELL 0520 - BASIC DATA for ABELL 0520 | publisher = NASA/IPAC EXTRAGALACTIC DATABASE | accessdate = March 3, 2012 }}</ref> | temperature = 9.8 [[electron volt|keV]]<ref name="Ebeling" /> | mass = 17{{e|14}} {{hub|0.70}}<ref name="Girardi" /> | luminosity = {{val|14.44|e=44}} [[erg]]/s (0.1–2.4 [[electron volt|keV]])<ref name="Ebeling" /> | flux = 8.4{{e|-12}} erg s<sup>−1</sup> cm<sup>−2</sup> (0.1–2.4 [[electron volt|keV]])<ref name="Ebeling" /> | other_names = The Train Wreck Cluster }}
[[File:a520 comp.jpg|309px|right|thumb|A520 pictured in [[X-ray]], [[optical]], and an inferred mass distribution based on the observed [[weak gravitational lensing]]. Imaged April 2007.]]
The '''Abell 520''' [[galaxy cluster]] possesses an unusual substructure resulting from a [[Galaxy merger#By size|major merger]]. It has been popularly nicknamed The '''Train Wreck Cluster''',<ref name=PW-Aug2007>{{cite web | url = http://physicsworld.com/cws/article/news/30849 | title = ‘Cosmic train wreck’ stumps dark-matter physicists | publisher = [[Physics World]] }}</ref><ref name=NS-Aug2007>{{cite web | url= https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn12497-cosmic-train-wreck-defies-dark-matter-theories.html | title = Cosmic 'train wreck' defies dark matter theories - space - | publisher = [[New Scientist]] | accessdate = 16 August 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://chandra.harvard.edu/photo/2007/a520/ | title = Abell 520: Dark Matter Mystery Deepens in Cosmic "Train Wreck" | accessdate = 16 August 2007 }}</ref> due to its chaotic structure, and is classified as a [[Bautz-Morgan type]] III cluster.<ref name="ACO" /> It is at a [[Distance measures (cosmology)#Comoving distance|co-moving radial distance]] of {{convert|811|Mpc|Mly|0|abbr=on|lk=on}} and [[Subtended angle|subtends]] 25 [[arcminutes]] on the sky.<ref name="NED"/> Analysis<ref name="Girardi">{{cite journal | journal = Astronomy and Astrophysics | title = Cluster Abell 520: a perspective based on member galaxies. A cluster forming at the crossing of three filaments? | author = Girardi, M. | author2 = Barrena, R. | author3 = Boschin, W. | author4 = Ellingson, E. | date = Nov 2008 | doi = 10.1051/0004-6361:200810549 | volume = 491 | pages = 379–395 | issue = 2 | arxiv = 0809.3139 | bibcode = 2008A&A...491..379G }}</ref> of the motions of 293 galaxies in the cluster field suggested that Abell 520 was a cluster forming at the crossing of three filaments of the large scale structure
The surprising substructure of Abell 520 was reported in 2007 from a weak gravitational lensing study based on Canada-France-Hawaii-Telescope (CFHT) imaging data. It was surprising because the study found the "dark core" with a significant amount of mass in the region, where there is no concentration of bright cluster galaxies. No conventional understanding of [[dark matter]] can explain this peculiar concentration of dark matter.<ref name=NS-Aug2007/><ref name=PW-Aug2007/> One interesting interpretation is that the substructure may arise from non-gravitational interaction of dark matter.
However, in the year 2012 two international teams of astronomers published conflicting results on Abell 520. While one study<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Jee | first = M. J. | last2 = Mahdavi | first2 = A. | last3 = Hoekstra | first3 = H. | last4 = Babul | first4 = A. | last5 = Dalcanton | first5 = J. J. | last6 = Carroll | first6 = P. | last7 = Capak | first7 = P. | date = 2012-03-01 | title = A Study of the Dark Core in A520 with the Hubble Space Telescope: The Mystery Deepens | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 747 | pages = 96 | doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/747/2/96 |arxiv = 1202.6368 |bibcode = 2012ApJ...747...96J }}</ref> based on the Wide Field Planetary Camera 2 (WFPC2) on Hubble Space Telescope (HST) confirmed the previous claim of the dark core in Abell 520, the other study<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Clowe | first = Douglas | last2 = Markevitch | first2 = Maxim | last3 = Bradac | first3 = Marusa | last4 = Gonzalez | first4 = Anthony H. | last5 = Chung | first5 = Sun Mi | last6 = Massey | first6 = Richard | last7 = Zaritsky | first7 = Dennis | date = 2012-10-01 | title = On Dark Peaks and Missing Mass: A Weak-lensing Mass Reconstruction of the Merging Cluster System A520 | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 758 | pages = 128 | doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/758/2/128 |arxiv = 1209.2143 |bibcode = 2012ApJ...758..128C }}</ref> based on the Advanced Camera for Surveys (ACS) did not support the claim.
In 2014, a study<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Jee | first = M. J. | last2 = Hoekstra | first2 = H. | last3 = Mahdavi | first3 = A. | last4 = Babul | first4 = A. | date = 2014-03-01 | title = Hubble Space Telescope/Advanced Camera for Surveys Confirmation of the Dark Substructure in A520 | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 783 | pages = 78 | doi = 10.1088/0004-637X/783/2/78 |arxiv = 1401.3356 |bibcode = 2014ApJ...783...78J }}</ref> of the ACS images by the original team claims to again have found evidence of a dark core, but is in a different location from the first two studies. A subsequent analysis<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Peel | first = A. | last2 = Lanusse | first2 = F. | last3 = Starck | first3 = J.-L. | date = 2017-09-01 | title = Sparse Reconstruction of the Merging A520 Cluster System | journal = The Astrophysical Journal | volume = 847 | pages = 13 | doi = 10.3874/1538-4357/aa840d |arxiv = 1708.00269 |bibcode = 2017ApJ...847...23P }}</ref> by an independent third team of the gravitational shear catalogs of the two competing ACS analyses indicates marginal evidence for the core in both data sets and the authors "do not consider A520 as posing a significant challenge to the collisionless dark matter scenario."
==See also== * [[Abell catalogue]] * [[Bullet Cluster]] * [[List of Abell clusters]] * [[List of galaxy clusters]]

'''Arc suppression''' is the reduction of sparks formed when current-carrying contacts are separated. The spark is a luminous discharge of highly energized electrons and ions, and is an [[electric arc]].{{cite web |title=Electric arc |publisher=[[TheFreeDictionary.com]] |url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/Electrical+arcing |accessdate=August 22, 2011}}{{cite web |last=Martin |first=T. L. |date=n.d. |title=Electric arcing |url=http://www.elr-electrical.co.za/Electrical%20arcing.html |accessdate=August 22, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331044755/http://www.elr-electrical.co.za/Electrical%20arcing.html |archivedate=2012-03-31}}{{cite book |first=A. M. |last=Howatson |title=An Introduction to Gas Discharges |edition=second |date=1976 |publisher=[[Pergamon Press]] |location=Oxford |pages=47–101 |isbn=9780080205755}}{{cite web |title=Contact Arc Phenomenon |url=http://www.multi-contact.com.sg/elesta/images/Technical%20Information.pdf |accessdate=August 22, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070813070535/http://www.multi-contact.com.sg/elesta/images/Technical%20Information.pdf |archivedate=2007-08-13}} ==Uses== [[File:Contacts - new and used.jpg|right|thumb|300px|
(left) Pristine contacts from a relay
(right) The nearly destroyed contacts from a relay operated under power for nearly 100,000 cycles]] There are several possible areas of use of arc suppression methods, among them [[Sputter deposition|metal film deposition and sputtering]], [[Arc flash#Protecting personnel|arc flash protection]], electrostatic processes where electrical arcs are not desired (such as [[powder painting]], [[Air purifier|air purification]], [[Polyvinylidene fluoride|PVDF]] film poling) and contact current arc suppression. In industrial, military and consumer electronic design, the latter method generally applies to devices such as electromechanical power switches, relays and contactors. In this context, arc suppression is [[contact protection]]. === Contact protection === Every time an electrical power device (for example: heaters, lamps, motors, transformers or similar power loads) turns on or off, its switch, relay or [[contactor]] transitions either from a closed to an open state (break arc) or from an open to a closed state (make arc & bounce arc), under load, an electrical arc occurs between the two contact points (electrodes) of the switch. The break arc is typically more energetic and thus more destructive.The National Association of Relay Manufacturers, Engineers’ Relay Handbook, NARM, 8th Edition, 1980, pg 245{{cite book |first=Perry L. |last=Martin |title=Electronic Failure Analysis Handbook |publisher=[[McGraw-Hill]] |date=1999 |pages=16.1–16.29 |ref=harv}} The temperature of the resulting [[electric arc]] is very high (tens of thousands of degrees), causing the metal on the contact surfaces to melt, pool and migrate with the current. The high temperature of the arc [[Dissociation (chemistry)|cracks]] the surrounding gas molecules creating ozone, carbon monoxide, and other compounds. The arc energy slowly destroys the contact metal, causing some material to escape into the air as fine particulate matter. This very activity causes the material in the contacts to degrade quickly, resulting in device failure.{{harvnb|Martin|1999|p=1.3}} Arc suppression is an area of interest in engineering because of the destructive effects of the electrical arc to electromechanical power switches, relays and [[contactor]]s’ points of contact.Tyco P&B, Contact ARC Phenomenon, Tyco Electronics Corporation – P&B, Winston-Salem, NC, Application Note 13C3203, pgs. 1-3 ==Effectiveness== [[File:Break arc on osciloscope.jpg|right|thumb|450px|Screen captures from an oscilloscope measuring the arc energy: current shown by blue line (sinusoidal wave), 2V/div = 5A/div; voltage shown by red line,10V/div.
(left) Unsuppressed AC power electrical arc
(right) An identical arc with suppression.]]The efficacy of an arc suppression solution for [[contact protection]] can be assessed, by comparing the arc intensity with the help of the following methods: *Visual Inspection of the arc: The electrical arc can be visually observed on an electromechanical power switch, relay and contactor, with visible contacts, while the contacts are opening and closing under load. *Graphical representation of measurements obtained by an oscilloscope: The electrical arc can be observed by using an oscilloscope to trace the voltage wave form across the contact terminals while the contacts are opening and closing under load. == Common devices == Common devices used to prevent arcs are capacitors, [[snubber]]s, diodes, Zener diodes, [[varistor]]s, and transient voltage suppressors.Tyco P&B, Relay Contact Life, Tyco Electronics Corporation – P&B, Winston-Salem, NC, Application Note 13C3236, pgs. 1-3 Contact arc suppression solutions that are considered more effective: #Two-wire contact arc suppressor #[[Solid state relay]]s are not electromechanical, have no contacts, and, thus, do not create electrical arcs.The National Association of Relay Manufacturers, Engineers’ Relay Handbook, NARM, 8th Edition, 1980, Chapter 13 #Hybrid power relays #Hybrid power contactors ==Benefits of Arc Suppression== Arc suppression techniques can produce a number of benefits:{{cite web | title = Features & Benefits Arc Suppression | url = http://www.electronic-components.com.au/products-services/arc-suppression/ | accessdate = December 6, 2013}} #Minimised contact damage from arcing and therefore reduced maintenance, repair and replacement frequency. #Increased Contact reliability. #Reduced heat generation resulting in less heat management measures such as venting and fans. #Reduced Ozone and pollutant emissions. #Reduced [[Electromagnetic Interference]] (EMI) from arcs - a common source of radiated EMI. ==See also== *[[Contact protection]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== *[http://www.leachintl2.com/english/english2/vol6/properties/faq.html Relays - Frequently Asked Questions] *[http://www.ieee.org/searchresults/index.html?cx=006539740418318249752%3Af2h38l7gvis&cof=FORID%3A11&qp=&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&q=arc+suppression&siteurl=www.ieee.org%2Findex.html#1169 Arc suppression articles] on [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]] website [[Category:Electric arcs]] [[Category:Electrical discharge in gases]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} The '''Bartlett street lamp''' was an economical type of [[Lighting#History|lighting]] first patented and manufactured by J. W. Bartlett at 569 [[Broadway (Manhattan)|Broadway]] in [[Manhattan]] in New York City, in 1872. Bartlett claimed his street lamps cost less than a quarter of the $25 ''[[The New York Times]]'' had reported a competitor claimed they cost. The ''Times'' responded that the [[New York City Parks Department]] said that they actually paid more than that for each lamp, including the post and frame, that they used in parks, streets, and elsewhere.<ref name=new/> The city of [[Troy, New York]] used the lamps beginning in 1872 to replace older models when they wore out.<ref>Classified Ad 2-No Title, March 28, 1874, p. 7.</ref>
==Advantages of use== According to Bartlett, a portion of the economy of the Bartlett street lamp was derived from the iron frames used in their construction. Other efficient qualities included a greater thickness of glass and less need for repair. Unless an object collided with a Bartlett street lamp with sufficient force, it would likely glance off of it. Likewise, drops of rain did not affect them after they were lighted. The ''Times'' disputed those contentions, saying the lamps were frequently cracked or broken.<ref name=new>[https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1872/02/04/78774824.pdf The Bartlett Street-Lamps], letter to the editor and response, ''[[The New York Times]]'', February 4, 1872, p. 5.</ref> [[Lamplighter]]s preferred them because they were easy to light and clean. Bartlett Street Lamps diffused light nicely, according to an advertisement.<ref>Classified Ad 8-No Title, ''The New York Times'', March 30, 1874, p. 5.</ref>
==Innovative manufacturer== J.W. Bartlett presented a claim for $1,796 against the Department of Public Parks of New York City, in February 1872.<ref>Auditing The Accounts, '' The New York Times'', February 23, 1872, p. 3.</ref> By mid-1878 Bartlett introduced several devices which enabled lamplighting via electricity which he produced from an office at 950 Broadway. There were three inventions which each related to the other. One was an electric gas cock and lighter, which was controlled by the hand and which could be adjusted upon any gas fixture. The second was an automatic gas [[Stopcock|cock]] and [[lighter]] used in street lights and buildings. The third was an electric signal. As an experiment the lamps around [[Madison Square]] were fitted with automatic lighters. Each could be lighted or extinguished in a short time by placing a finger on the button of a battery at the office at 950 Broadway. Also the battery could be connected to a clock and the lights extinguished in just a moment.<ref>Lamp-Lighting By Electricity, ''The New York Times'', June 8, 1878, p. 8.</ref>
==Manufacturing sites== The ''Railroad, Telegraph and Steamship Builders' Directory'' of 1888 lists a Bartlett Street Lamp Co., at 35 Howard Street in New York. It also mentions Bartlett Street Lamp Mfg. Co., at 42 College Place in New York.<ref>''Railroad, Telegraph and Steamship Builders' Directory'', The Railway Directory Publishing Company, 1888, p. 189.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

The foundation stone for the dam was laid on 18 February 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Laying the foundation stone for a number of vital projects in the district Amedee|url=http://www.krg.org/a/print.aspx?l=14&smap=010000&a=33872|publisher=KRG.org|accessdate=31 January 2014|language=Arabic}}</ref>

{{Other uses2|Blue Gold}} {{Infobox film | name = Blue Gold: World Water Wars | image = Blue Gold World Water Wars poster.jpg | caption = | director = [[Sam Bozzo]] | producer = [[Mark Achbar]]
Si Litvinoff
Sam Bozzo | writer = Sam Bozzo
[[Maude Barlow]]
[[Tony Clarke (activist)|Tony Clarke]] | narrator = [[Malcolm McDowell]] | music = [http://de.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hannes_Bertolini&stable=1 Hannes Bertolini]
Thomas Aichinger | cinematography = | editing = Sam Bozzo | distributor = [[PBS]] | released = {{Film date|2008|10|07|Vancouver International Film Festival}} | runtime = 89 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = }} '''''Blue Gold: World Water Wars''''' is a 2008 [[documentary film]] directed, co-produced, and co-written by [[Sam Bozzo]],{{cite web | last = GreenMuze Staff | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Blue Gold: World Water Wars. An Interview With Film Director Sam Bozzo | work = | publisher = | date = August 27, 2008 | url = http://www.greenmuze.com/news/breaking-news/297-blue-gold.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090307020031/http://www.greenmuze.com/news/breaking-news/297-blue-gold.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = March 7, 2009 | doi = | accessdate = May 25, 2009 | df = }} based on the book ''Blue Gold: The Fight to Stop the Corporate Theft of the World’s Water'' by [[Maude Barlow]] and [[Tony Clarke (activist)|Tony Clarke]].{{cite journal | last = Larraine Cox | first = Jan | title = Water Water Everywhere: Blue Gold at the Kent Film Festival | journal = | volume = Chronogram Magazine | date = February 27, 2009 | url = http://www.chronogram.com/issue/2009/3/Arts+&+Culture/Water-Water-Everywhere | accessdate = May 26, 2009}} It was produced by [[Mark Achbar]] and Si Litvinoff and was narrated by [[Malcolm McDowell]]. The film was first screened on October 9, 2008, at the [[Vancouver International Film Festival]].{{Cite news | last = Ferreras | first = Jesse | title = Blue Gold examines the politics of water | newspaper = north shore news | date = 26 September 2008 | url = http://www2.canada.com/northshorenews/news/pulse/story.html?id=56054a92-95ff-4efd-ae83-db2522cce94e&p=2 | format = }} {{dead link|date=April 2010}} ==Synopsis== ''Blue Gold: World Water Wars'' examines environmental and political implications of the planet's dwindling water supply, and posits that wars in the future will be fought over water.{{cite web|url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2009/04/film-review-blue-gold-world-water-wars.php|title=Film Review - Blue Gold: World Water Wars|work=TreeHugger}} The film also highlights some success stories of water activists around the world. ==Critical reception and awards== *Audience award for Best Environmental Film at the Vancouver International Film Festivalhttp://www.cbmc.ca/news/story/2008/10/11/vancouver-film-awards.html{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://www.documentary.org/content/awards-roundup-october-1-13-2008|title=Awards Roundup: October 1-13, 2008|work=International Documentary Association}} *Ecology Now! award at the European Independent Film Festival{{cite web|url=http://www.documentary.org/content/awards-roundup-march-18-24-2009|title=Awards Roundup: March 18-24, 2009|work=International Documentary Association}} *Jury prize for best documentary feature at the [[Newport Beach Film Festival]]{{cite news | last = Chang | first = Richard | title = It's a wrap for the Newport Beach Film Festival | work = The OC Register | publisher = | date = May 4, 2009 | url = http://m.ocregister.com/ocregister/db_13118/contentdetail.htm;jsessionid=87B62B83E3D66E6788FE3B61BDEF39CE?contentguid=L6DMXMXF&detailindex=6&pn=0&ps=10&full=true | accessdate = May 25, 2009}} ==See also== *[[Water crisis]] *[[Water politics]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.bluegold-worldwaterwars.com/}} * {{IMDb title|1137439}} [[Category:2008 films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about water and the environment]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films about activists]] [[Category:Water scarcity]] {{environment-documentary-film-stub}}

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=June 2016}}
{{Infobox machine | name = Cartridge Heater | image = Types-of-cartridge-heaters.jpg | caption = From top to bottom: Square cartridge heater, cartridge heater with threaded NPT fitting (tapered threads), "mini" cartridge heater. | industry = Process heating }}
A '''cartridge heater''' is a tube-shaped, heavy-duty, industrial [[Joule heating]] element used in the process heating industry, usually custom manufactured to a specific watt density,<ref>http://www.omega.com/prodinfo/cartridgeheaters.html</ref> based on its intended application.<ref>http://www.process-heating.com/Articles/Feature_Article/154bd7dd2f268010VgnVCM100000f932a8c0____</ref> Compact designs are capable of reaching a watt density of up to 50W/cm².<ref>http://www.freek-heaters.com/products/cartridge_heaters/cartridge_heaters.php</ref><ref>http://www.backermarathon.com/products/hotrod/</ref>
==Applications==
Cartridge heaters are found useful in many applications,<ref>http://www.nexthermal.com/product/cartridge-heaters/high-watt-density-cartridge-heaters.aspx</ref> such as:
* Seal bars *Torpedo heaters for injection molding * Injection molding manifolds * Mass spectrometry * Rubber molding * Food production * Immersion tank heating * HVAC compressors * Fuel cells * Semiconductors * Medical devices * Sensor measurement devices * Extrusion * Die casting * Hot melt adhesives * Heat staking / hole punch * Plastic welding * Fluid heating * 3D Printers
<gallery> File:Cartridge-heater-cold.jpg|Cold cartridge heater File:Cartridge-heater-hot.jpg|Hot cartridge heater </gallery>
==Construction==
Construction of a cartridge heater may be divided in 7 main parts: * Heating coil * Insulation * Sheath * Sealing * Termination * Lead wire type * Watt density
===Heating coil===
The heating coil is the actual resistance which is where the electrical load occurs. The most common type of metal alloy used for this purpose is a nickel-chromium mixture, also known as [[nichrome]]. The nichrome wire is wound around a ceramic core, and the number of spirals per inch vary according to the requested watt density. Potential from an alternating current source, which can either be 2 phase or 3 phase, flows through the coiled nichrome wire, heating up the wire, which in turn, heats the cartridge heater sheath.
===Insulation===
Insulation is used to prevent the nichrome coil contacting the sheath, an event that would ground the resistance and could produce a catastrophic short-circuit, resulting in a melted sheath and a major equipment failure. Damage can be mitigated by installing a ground fault interrupting circuit. To prevent the coil from touching the sheath, the coil is inserted into the sheath, and immediately filled with [[magnesium oxide]] (MgO). To ensure the MgO fills the empty space between the sheath and the coil, the cartridge heater is filled under vibration.
===Sheath===
The sheath is the part of the cartridge heater which makes contact with the material or substance to be heated. Several metal alloys are used, depending on the type of application, such as highly acidic or corrosive environments. The most common types of sheaths are 304 [[stainless steel]], 316 stainless steel, and incoloy 800. Incoloy has the highest temperature rating, and is considered a [[superalloy]].
===Sealing===
After the cartridge heater has been filled with MgO, a seal is applied to the open end of the cartridge heater (where the nichrome coil was introduced). This prevents the coil and the MgO from coming out, as well as preventing contaminants such as plastic debris, air, or moisture from entering the heater.
===Termination===
Since cartridge heaters are installed in a wide variety of machines, manufacturers must design the heaters to meet certain clearances.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bigchiefheaters.com/insert1h.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110206013257/http://www.bigchiefheaters.com/insert1h.htm |archivedate=2011-02-06 |df= }}</ref> [dead link] The cartridge heaters might be terminated with the leads coming out straight, or in a right angle. Also, manufacturers must be careful that the leads are not exposed to temperatures higher than the maximum rating for the lead wire. In order to prevent lead wire damage from temperature, movement or contamination, the lead wire can be protected with a metal conduit, braided metal or silicone sleeves.<ref>http://freek-heaters.com/products/cartridge_heaters/options_for_cartridge_heaters.php</ref>
=== Lead wire type ===
Depending on the clearance and the design of the machine where the cartridge heater will be inserted, the type of wire used will vary. [[Fiberglass]] is the commonly used for cartridge heaters and other high-temperature applications, such as automotive wiring harnesses and industrial equipment. Other variants used are [[silicone]] impregnated fiberglass and [[silicone rubber]].
==References== {{Reflist}} http://www.gimido.com/
==External links== *[http://www.backermarathon.com/products/cartridge-heaters/ Sheath Materials] *[http://www.resisten.com.br/resistencia-cartucho/ Resistência Cartucho]
[[Category:Heating]]
